trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 5. Reconfigure clients to use Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 5. Reconfigure clients to use Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: For Windows clients:
trans-unit.target: For Windows clients:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Download the migration scripts</linkText><title></title></link>:
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Download the migration scripts</linkText><title></title></link>:

trans-unit.source: CleanUpRMS_RUN_Elevated.cmd
trans-unit.target: CleanUpRMS_RUN_Elevated.cmd

trans-unit.source: Redirect_OnPrem.cmd
trans-unit.target: Redirect_OnPrem.cmd

trans-unit.source: These scripts reset the configuration on Windows computers so that they will use the Azure RMS service rather than AD RMS.
trans-unit.target: These scripts reset the configuration on Windows computers so that they will use the Azure RMS service rather than AD RMS.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in the redirection script (Redirect_OnPrem.cmd) to modify the script to point to your new Azure RMS tenant.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in the redirection script (Redirect_OnPrem.cmd) to modify the script to point to your new Azure RMS tenant.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows computers, run these scripts with elevated privileges in the user’s context.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows computers, run these scripts with elevated privileges in the user’s context.

trans-unit.source: For mobile device clients and Mac computers:
trans-unit.target: For mobile device clients and Mac computers:

trans-unit.source: Remove the DNS SRV records that you created when you deployed the <link><linkText>AD RMS mobile device extension</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Remove the DNS SRV records that you created when you deployed the <link><linkText>AD RMS mobile device extension</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Changes made by the migration scripts
trans-unit.target: Changes made by the migration scripts

trans-unit.source: This section documents the changes that the migration scripts make.
trans-unit.target: This section documents the changes that the migration scripts make.

trans-unit.source: You can use this information for reference purposes only, or for troubleshooting, or if you prefer to make these changes yourself.
trans-unit.target: You can use this information for reference purposes only, or for troubleshooting, or if you prefer to make these changes yourself.

trans-unit.source: CleanUpRMS_RUN_Elevated.cmd:
trans-unit.target: CleanUpRMS_RUN_Elevated.cmd:

trans-unit.source: Delete the contents of the %userprofile%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\DRM and %userprofile%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\MSIPC folders, including any subfolders and any files with long file names.
trans-unit.target: Delete the contents of the %userprofile%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\DRM and %userprofile%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\MSIPC folders, including any subfolders and any files with long file names.

trans-unit.source: Delete the contents of the following registry keys:
trans-unit.target: Delete the contents of the following registry keys:

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSIPC\ServiceLocation
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSIPC\ServiceLocation

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\MSIPC\ServiceLocation
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\MSIPC\ServiceLocation

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSDRM\ServiceLocation
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSDRM\ServiceLocation

trans-unit.source: Delete the following registry values:
trans-unit.target: Delete the following registry values:

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\15.0\Common\DRM\DefaultServerURL
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\15.0\Common\DRM\DefaultServerURL

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\15.0\Common\DRM\DefaultServer
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\15.0\Common\DRM\DefaultServer

trans-unit.source: Redirect_OnPrem.cmd:
trans-unit.target: Redirect_OnPrem.cmd:

trans-unit.source: Create the following registry values for each URL supplied as a parameter under each of the following locations:
trans-unit.target: Create the following registry values for each URL supplied as a parameter under each of the following locations:

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\WoW6432Node\Microsoft\Office\(11.0|12.0|14.0)\Common\DRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.source: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\Local Settings\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\LicensingRedirection
trans-unit.target: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\Local Settings\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\LicensingRedirection

trans-unit.source: Each entry has a REG_SZ value of https://OldRMSserverURL/_wmcs/licensing with the data in the following format: https:///_wmcs/licensing.
trans-unit.target: Each entry has a REG_SZ value of https://OldRMSserverURL/_wmcs/licensing with the data in the following format: https:///_wmcs/licensing.

trans-unit.source: has the following format: {GUID}.rms.[Region].aadrm.com.
trans-unit.target: has the following format: {GUID}.rms.[Region].aadrm.com.

trans-unit.source: For example: 5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com
trans-unit.target: For example: 5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com

trans-unit.source: You can find this value by identifying the RightsManagementServiceId value when you run the Get-AadrmConfiguration cmdlet for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: You can find this value by identifying the RightsManagementServiceId value when you run the Get-AadrmConfiguration cmdlet for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 6. Configure IRM integration for Exchange Online
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 6. Configure IRM integration for Exchange Online

trans-unit.source: If you have previously imported your TDP from AD RMS to Exchange Online, you must remove this TDP to avoid conflicting templates and policies after you have migrated to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: If you have previously imported your TDP from AD RMS to Exchange Online, you must remove this TDP to avoid conflicting templates and policies after you have migrated to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: To do this, use the <link><linkText>Remove-RMSTrustedPublishingDomain</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet from Exchange Online.
trans-unit.target: To do this, use the <link><linkText>Remove-RMSTrustedPublishingDomain</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet from Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: If you chose an Azure RMS tenant key topology of Microsoft managed:
trans-unit.target: If you chose an Azure RMS tenant key topology of Microsoft managed:

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>Exchange Online: IRM Configuration</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Configuring Applications for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>Exchange Online: IRM Configuration</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Configuring Applications for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: This section includes typical commands to run that connects to the Exchange Online service, imports the tenant key from Azure RMS, and enables IRM functionality for Exchange Online.
trans-unit.target: This section includes typical commands to run that connects to the Exchange Online service, imports the tenant key from Azure RMS, and enables IRM functionality for Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: After you complete these steps, you will have full RMS functionality with Exchange Online.
trans-unit.target: After you complete these steps, you will have full RMS functionality with Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: If you chose an Azure RMS tenant key topology of customer-managed (BYOK):
trans-unit.target: If you chose an Azure RMS tenant key topology of customer-managed (BYOK):

trans-unit.source: You will have reduced RMS functionality with Exchange Online, as described in the <link><linkText>BYOK pricing and restrictions</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: You will have reduced RMS functionality with Exchange Online, as described in the <link><linkText>BYOK pricing and restrictions</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 7. Deploy the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 7. Deploy the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: If you have used the Information Rights Management (IRM) functionality of Exchange Server or SharePoint Server with AD RMS, you must first disable IRM on these servers and remove AD RMS configuration.
trans-unit.target: If you have used the Information Rights Management (IRM) functionality of Exchange Server or SharePoint Server with AD RMS, you must first disable IRM on these servers and remove AD RMS configuration.

trans-unit.source: Then, deploy the Rights Management (RMS) connector, which acts as a communications interface (a relay) between the on-premises servers and Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Then, deploy the Rights Management (RMS) connector, which acts as a communications interface (a relay) between the on-premises servers and Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: Finally for this step, if you have imported multiple TPDs into Azure RMS that were used to protect email messages, you must manually edit the registry on the Exchange Server computers to redirect all TPDs URLs to the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Finally for this step, if you have imported multiple TPDs into Azure RMS that were used to protect email messages, you must manually edit the registry on the Exchange Server computers to redirect all TPDs URLs to the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Before you start, check the supported versions of the on-premises servers that the RMS connector supports in “On-premises servers that support Azure RMS” in the <link><linkText>Applications that support Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> section of the <link><linkText>Requirements for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: Before you start, check the supported versions of the on-premises servers that the RMS connector supports in “On-premises servers that support Azure RMS” in the <link><linkText>Applications that support Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> section of the <link><linkText>Requirements for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: Disable IRM on Exchange Servers and remove AD RMS configuration
trans-unit.target: Disable IRM on Exchange Servers and remove AD RMS configuration

trans-unit.source: On each Exchange server, locate the following folder and delete all the entries in that folder: \ProgramData\Microsoft\DRM\Server\S-1-5-18
trans-unit.target: On each Exchange server, locate the following folder and delete all the entries in that folder: \ProgramData\Microsoft\DRM\Server\S-1-5-18

trans-unit.source: From one of the Exchange servers, use the Exchange <link><linkText>Set_IRMConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to first disable IRM features for messages that are sent to internal recipients:
trans-unit.target: From one of the Exchange servers, use the Exchange <link><linkText>Set_IRMConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to first disable IRM features for messages that are sent to internal recipients:

trans-unit.source: Then use the same cmdlet to disable IRM features for messages that are sent to external recipients:
trans-unit.target: Then use the same cmdlet to disable IRM features for messages that are sent to external recipients:

trans-unit.source: Next, use the same cmdlet to disable IRM in Microsoft Office Outlook Web App and in Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync:
trans-unit.target: Next, use the same cmdlet to disable IRM in Microsoft Office Outlook Web App and in Microsoft Exchange ActiveSync:

trans-unit.source: Finally, use the same cmdlet to clear any cached certificates:
trans-unit.target: Finally, use the same cmdlet to clear any cached certificates:

trans-unit.source: On each Exchange Server, now reset IIS, for example, by running a command prompt as an administrator and typing iisreset.
trans-unit.target: On each Exchange Server, now reset IIS, for example, by running a command prompt as an administrator and typing iisreset.

trans-unit.source: Disable IRM on SharePoint Servers and remove AD RMS configuration
trans-unit.target: Disable IRM on SharePoint Servers and remove AD RMS configuration

trans-unit.source: Make sure that there are no documents checked out from RMS-protected libraries.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that there are no documents checked out from RMS-protected libraries.

trans-unit.source: If there are, they will be become inaccessible at the end of this procedure.
trans-unit.target: If there are, they will be become inaccessible at the end of this procedure.

trans-unit.source: On the SharePoint Central Administration Web site, in the Quick Launch section, click Security.
trans-unit.target: On the SharePoint Central Administration Web site, in the Quick Launch section, click Security.

trans-unit.source: On the Security page, in the Information Policy section, click Configure information rights management.
trans-unit.target: On the Security page, in the Information Policy section, click Configure information rights management.

trans-unit.source: On the Information Rights Management page, in the Information Rights Management section, select Do not use IRM on this server, then click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the Information Rights Management page, in the Information Rights Management section, select Do not use IRM on this server, then click OK.

trans-unit.source: On each of the SharePoint Server computers, delete the contents of the folder \ProgramData\Microsoft\MSIPC\Server\.
trans-unit.target: On each of the SharePoint Server computers, delete the contents of the folder \ProgramData\Microsoft\MSIPC\Server\.

trans-unit.source: Install and configure the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: Install and configure the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: Use the instructions in the <link><linkText>Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: Use the instructions in the <link><linkText>Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: For Exchange only and multiple TPDs: Edit the registry
trans-unit.target: For Exchange only and multiple TPDs: Edit the registry

trans-unit.source: On each Exchange Server, manually add the following registry keys for each additional TPD that you imported, to redirect the TPD URLs to the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: On each Exchange Server, manually add the following registry keys for each additional TPD that you imported, to redirect the TPD URLs to the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: These registry entries are specific to migration and are not added by the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: These registry entries are specific to migration and are not added by the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: When you make these registry edits, use the following instructions:
trans-unit.target: When you make these registry edits, use the following instructions:

trans-unit.source: Replace ConnectorFQDN with the name that you defined in DNS for the connector.
trans-unit.target: Replace ConnectorFQDN with the name that you defined in DNS for the connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: Use the HTTP or HTTPS prefix for the connector URL, depending on whether you have configured the connector to use HTTP or HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.
trans-unit.target: Use the HTTP or HTTPS prefix for the connector URL, depending on whether you have configured the connector to use HTTP or HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.

trans-unit.source: For Exchange 2013:
trans-unit.target: For Exchange 2013:

trans-unit.target: Registry path

trans-unit.target: Value

trans-unit.target: Data

trans-unit.target: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ExchangeServer\v15\IRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.target: Reg_SZ

trans-unit.target: https://<AD RMS Intranet Licensing URL>/_wmcs/licensing

trans-unit.target: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ExchangeServer\v14\IRM\LicenseServerRedirection

trans-unit.source: Reg_SZ
trans-unit.target: Reg_SZ

trans-unit.source: https://<AD RMS Extranet Licensing URL>/_wmcs/licensing
trans-unit.target: https://<AD RMS Extranet Licensing URL>/_wmcs/licensing

trans-unit.source: One of the following, depending on whether you are using HTTP or HTTPS from your Exchange server to the RMS connector:<html></html><html></html>http://<connectorName>/_wmcs/licensing<html></html><html></html>https://<connectorName>/_wmcs/licensing
trans-unit.target: One of the following, depending on whether you are using HTTP or HTTPS from your Exchange server to the RMS connector:<html></html><html></html>http://<connectorName>/_wmcs/licensing<html></html><html></html>https://<connectorName>/_wmcs/licensing

trans-unit.source: After you have completed these procedures, be sure to read the Next steps section in the Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector topic.
trans-unit.target: After you have completed these procedures, be sure to read the Next steps section in the Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector topic.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 8. Decommission AD RMS
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 8. Decommission AD RMS

trans-unit.source: Optional: Remove the Service Connection Point (SCP) from Active Directory to prevent computers from discovering your on-premises Rights Management infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Optional: Remove the Service Connection Point (SCP) from Active Directory to prevent computers from discovering your on-premises Rights Management infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: This is optional because of the redirection that you configured in the registry (for example, by running the migration script).
trans-unit.target: This is optional because of the redirection that you configured in the registry (for example, by running the migration script).

trans-unit.source: To remove the Service Connection Point, use the AD SCP Register tool from the <link><linkText>Rights Management Services Administration Toolkit</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To remove the Service Connection Point, use the AD SCP Register tool from the <link><linkText>Rights Management Services Administration Toolkit</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Monitor your AD RMS servers for activity, for example, by checking the <link><linkText>requests in the System Health report</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>ServiceRequest table</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>auditing of user access to protected content</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Monitor your AD RMS servers for activity, for example, by checking the <link><linkText>requests in the System Health report</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>ServiceRequest table</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>auditing of user access to protected content</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When you have confirmed that RMS clients are no longer communicating with these servers and that clients are successfully using Azure RMS, you can remove the AD RMS server role from these server.
trans-unit.target: When you have confirmed that RMS clients are no longer communicating with these servers and that clients are successfully using Azure RMS, you can remove the AD RMS server role from these server.

trans-unit.source: If you’re using dedicated servers, you might prefer the cautionary step of first shutting down the servers for a period of time to make sure that there are no reported problems that might require restarting these servers to ensure service continuity while you investigate why clients are not using Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: If you’re using dedicated servers, you might prefer the cautionary step of first shutting down the servers for a period of time to make sure that there are no reported problems that might require restarting these servers to ensure service continuity while you investigate why clients are not using Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: After decommissioning your AD RMS servers, you might want to take the opportunity to review your templates in the Azure classic portal and consolidate them so that users have fewer to choose between, or reconfigure them, or even add new templates.
trans-unit.target: After decommissioning your AD RMS servers, you might want to take the opportunity to review your templates in the Azure classic portal and consolidate them so that users have fewer to choose between, or reconfigure them, or even add new templates.

trans-unit.source: This would be also a good time to publish the default templates.
trans-unit.target: This would be also a good time to publish the default templates.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configuring Custom Templates for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configuring Custom Templates for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 9. Re-key your Azure RMS tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 9. Re-key your Azure RMS tenant key

trans-unit.source: This step is required when migration is complete if your AD RMS deployment was using RMS Cryptographic Mode 1, because re-keying creates a new tenant key that uses RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.
trans-unit.target: This step is required when migration is complete if your AD RMS deployment was using RMS Cryptographic Mode 1, because re-keying creates a new tenant key that uses RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure RMS with Cryptographic Mode 1 is supported only during the migration process.
trans-unit.target: Using Azure RMS with Cryptographic Mode 1 is supported only during the migration process.

trans-unit.source: This step is optional but recommended when migration is complete even if you were running in RMS Cryptographic Mode 2, because it helps to secure your Azure RMS tenant key from potential security breaches to your AD RMS key.
trans-unit.target: This step is optional but recommended when migration is complete even if you were running in RMS Cryptographic Mode 2, because it helps to secure your Azure RMS tenant key from potential security breaches to your AD RMS key.

trans-unit.source: When you re-key your Azure RMS tenant key (also known as “rolling your key”), a new key is created and the original key is archived.
trans-unit.target: When you re-key your Azure RMS tenant key (also known as “rolling your key”), a new key is created and the original key is archived.

trans-unit.source: However, because moving from one key to another doesn’t happen immediately but over a few weeks, do not wait until you suspect a breach to your original key but re-key your RMS tenant key as soon as the migration is complete.
trans-unit.target: However, because moving from one key to another doesn’t happen immediately but over a few weeks, do not wait until you suspect a breach to your original key but re-key your RMS tenant key as soon as the migration is complete.

trans-unit.source: To re-key your Azure RMS tenant key:
trans-unit.target: To re-key your Azure RMS tenant key:

trans-unit.source: If your RMS tenant key is managed by Microsoft: Call Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) and prove that you are the RMS tenant administrator.
trans-unit.target: If your RMS tenant key is managed by Microsoft: Call Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) and prove that you are the RMS tenant administrator.

trans-unit.source: If your RMS tenant key is managed by you (BYOK): Repeat the BYOK procedure to generate and create a new key over the Internet or in person.
trans-unit.target: If your RMS tenant key is managed by you (BYOK): Repeat the BYOK procedure to generate and create a new key over the Internet or in person.

trans-unit.source: For more information about managing your RMS tenant key, see <link><linkText>Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about managing your RMS tenant key, see <link><linkText>Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.
